xxl.core.collections.queues

Class BoundedQueue<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.collections.queues.DecoratorQueue<E>
      • xxl.core.collections.queues.BoundedQueue<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements of this queue.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Queue<E>, Decorator<Queue<E>>

    public class BoundedQueue<E>
extends DecoratorQueue<E>
    Decorates an arbitrary queue by adding boundary conditions.
    These conditions are represented as a user-defined, unary predicate which is applied to next element to be inserted into the underlying queue. If an insert operation detects an overflow, i.e., the predicate returns false, the method handleOverflow() is called. The default implementation throws an IndexOutOfBoundsException, but overwriting this method offers the possibility to handle an overflow of the underlying queue differently. If the predicate returns false, the element will be inserted into the underlying queue.
    For the construction of a bounded buffer, this class has proven to be useful.

    This class is used in ThreadedIterator.

    Example usage (1). 

         // create a new bounded queue using an ArrayQueue
 
     Queue<Integer> queue = new BoundedQueue<Integer>(new ArrayQueue<Integer>(), 100);

     // open the queue

     queue.open();

     try {
         Iterator<Integer> iterator = new xxl.core.cursors.sources.Enumerator(200);
         for (; iterator.hasNext(); queue.enqueue(iterator.next()));
     }
     catch (IndexOutOfBoundsException e) {}

     int count = queue.size();
     System.out.println("The queue contained "+count+
                        " elements (100 is correct!)");

      // close the queue

      queue.close();
    See Also:
    Queue, DecoratorQueue

    • Field Detail

      • FACTORY_METHOD

        public static final Function<Object,BoundedQueue<Object>> FACTORY_METHOD
        A factory method to create a new bounded queue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). It may be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of object arrays, an iterator or without any parameters. A parameter list of object arrays will be used to initialize the internally used array with the object array at index 0 and an iterator will be used to insert the contained elements into the new ArrayQueue.
        See Also:
        Function

      • predicate

        protected Predicate<? super E> predicate
        Predicate that evaluates if a further element can be inserted. Unary predicate that gets the next element to be inserted as parameter. If false is returned, an overflow must be handled, so the method handleOverflow() is called. Otherwise (true is returned), the element specified as argument will be inserted into the queue.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BoundedQueue

        public BoundedQueue(Queue<E> queue,
                    Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Constructs a BoundedQueue. The queue to become bounded must be passed as the first argument. The second argument is a predicate evaluating the next element and determining if an overflow must be handled.
        Parameters:
        queue - the queue that becomes bounded.
        predicate - the predicate evaluating the next element and determining if an overflow must be handled, i.e. handleOverflow() will be called, if the predicate returns false.

      • BoundedQueue

        public BoundedQueue(Queue<E> queue,
                    int maxSize)
        Constructs a BoundedQueue. The queue to become bounded must be passed as the first argument. The second argument defines the size of the queue.
        Parameters:
        queue - the queue that becomes bounded.
        maxSize - the size of the queue. If more elements become inserted method handleOverflow() is called.

    • Method Detail

      • enqueue

        public void enqueue(E object)
             throws IllegalStateException,
                    IndexOutOfBoundsException
        Appends the specified element to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy.
        Specified by:
        enqueue in interface Queue<E>
        Overrides:
        enqueue in class DecoratorQueue<E>
        Parameters:
        object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the queue is already closed when this method is called.
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the overflow cannot be handled.

      • handleOverflow

        public void handleOverflow()
                    throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
        If an insert operation detects an overflow, i.e., the maximum number of objects has been inserted into the queue, and a further element is to be inserted this method is called. The default implementation throws an IndexOutOfBoundsException, but overwriting this method offers the possibility to handle an overflow in the queue differently.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the overflow cannot be handled.
